brief_description of the content in the: The content discusses the use of @Cacheable annotation in Spring Core. It explains that in proxy mode, only external method calls coming through the proxy are intercepted. Therefore, self-invocation, i.e., a method within the target object calling another method of the target object, will not lead to actual caching at runtime even if the invoked method is marked with @Cacheable.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'cacheable_self_invocation' checks all classes and their methods in the application. If a method is annotated with @Cacheable, it checks for any calls within that method to other methods in the same class (self-invocation). If such a call exists, it asserts that the invoked method is not unique. If the assertion fails, it means that the self-invocation will not lead to actual caching at runtime even though it's marked with @Cacheable, and a message is displayed with the method and class names.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-cache-self-invocation
Summary: This article on Baeldung explains the issue of self-invocation in Spring caching. It confirms that self-invocations do not trigger the cache aspect, which aligns with the rule generated.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16899604/spring-cache-cacheable-method-ignored-when-called-from-within-the-same-class
Summary: This StackOverflow thread discusses a problem where a @Cacheable method is ignored when called from within the same class, which is the issue our rule is designed to detect.
